functions.name: IsConsoleVisible
functions.description: Returns whether the console is visible or not.

returnValues.description: Whether the console is visible or not.

functions.name: IsGameUIVisible
functions.description: Returns whether the game menu overlay ( main menu ) is open or not.

returnValues.description: Whether the game menu overlay ( main menu ) is open or not

functions.name: MousePos
functions.description:
<deprecated>Use <page>input.GetCursorPos</page> instead.</deprecated>

Returns the cursor's position on the screen, or 0, 0 if cursor is not visible.

functions.name: MouseX
functions.description: Returns x component of the mouse position.

functions.name: MouseY
functions.description: Returns y component of the mouse position.

functions.name: OpenURL
functions.description:
Opens specified URL in the steam overlay browser.

<note>When called clientside, user will be asked for confirmation before the website will open.</note>

arguments.name: url
arguments.description: URL to open, it has to start with either `http://` or `https://`.

functions.name: ScreenToVector
functions.description:
Converts the specified screen position to a **direction** vector local to the player's view. A related function is <page>Vector:ToScreen</page>, which translates a 3D position to a screen coordinate.

<page>util.AimVector</page> is a more generic version of this, using a custom view instead of the player's current view.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: X coordinate on the screen.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Y coordinate on the screen.

functions.name: SetMousePos
functions.description:
<deprecated>Use <page>input.SetCursorPos</page> instead.</deprecated>
Sets the cursor's position on the screen, relative to the topleft corner of the window

arguments.name: mouseX
arguments.description: The X coordinate to move the cursor to.

arguments.name: mouseY
arguments.description: The Y coordinate to move the cursor to.

functions.name: ShowConsole
functions.description: Shows console in the game UI.

name: GWEN
description: GWEN is a system that allows you to load a spritesheet and generate a skin out of it.

functions.name: CreateTextureBorder
functions.description:
Used in derma skins to create a bordered rectangle drawing function from an image.

The texture is taken from `SKIN.GwenTexture` when the `material` argument is not supplied.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X coordinate on the texture.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y coordinate on the texture.

arguments.name: w
arguments.description: Width of the area on texture.

arguments.name: h
arguments.description: Height of the area on texture.

arguments.name: left
arguments.description: Left width of border.

arguments.name: top
arguments.description: Top width of border.

arguments.name: right
arguments.description: Right width of border.

arguments.name: bottom
arguments.description: Bottom width of border.

arguments.name: material
arguments.description: If set, given material will be used over the SKIN's default material, which is `SKIN.GwenTexture`.

returnValues.name: drawFunc
returnValues.description:
The drawing function.
<callback>
<arg name="x" type="number">X coordinate for the box.</arg>
<arg name="y" type="number">Y coordinate for the box.</arg>
<arg name="w" type="number">Width of the box.</arg>
<arg name="h" type="number">Height of the box.</arg>
<arg name="clr" type="table" default="color_white">Optional color, default is white. Uses the <page>Color</page>.</arg>
</callback>

functions.name: CreateTextureCentered
functions.description:
Used in derma skins to create a rectangle drawing function from an image. The rectangle will not be scaled, but instead it will be drawn in the center of the box.

The texture is taken from `SKIN.GwenTexture` when the `material` is not supplied.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X coordinate on the texture

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y coordinate on the texture

arguments.name: w
arguments.description: Width of the area on texture

arguments.name: h
arguments.description: Height of the area on texture

arguments.name: material
arguments.description: If set, given material will be used over the SKIN's default material, which is `SKIN.GwenTexture`.

returnValues.description:
The drawing function.

<callback>
<arg name="x" type="number">X coordinate for the box.</arg>
<arg name="y" type="number">Y coordinate for the box.</arg>
<arg name="w" type="number">Width of the box.</arg>
<arg name="h" type="number">Height of the box.</arg>
<arg name="clr" type="table" default="color_white">Optional color, default is white. Uses the <page>Color</page>.</arg>
</callback>

functions.name: CreateTextureNormal
functions.description:
Used in derma skins to create a rectangle drawing function from an image. The texture of the rectangle will be scaled.

The texture is taken from `SKIN.GwenTexture` when the `material` is not supplied.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X coordinate on the texture

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y coordinate on the texture

arguments.name: w
arguments.description: Width of the area on texture

arguments.name: h
arguments.description: Height of the area on texture

arguments.name: material
arguments.description: If set, given material will be used over the SKIN's default material, which is `SKIN.GwenTexture`.

returnValues.description:
The drawing function.

<callback>
<arg name="x" type="number">X coordinate for the box.</arg>
<arg name="y" type="number">Y coordinate for the box.</arg>
<arg name="w" type="number">Width of the box.</arg>
<arg name="h" type="number">Height of the box.</arg>
<arg name="clr" type="table" default="color_white">Optional color, default is white. Uses the <page>Color</page>.</arg>
</callback>

functions.name: TextureColor
functions.description: When used in a material skin, it returns a color value from a point in the skin image.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: X position of the pixel to get the color from.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Y position of the pixel to get the color from.

returnValues.description: The color of the point on the skin as a <page>Color</page>.

name: halo
description: The halo library is used to draw glowing outlines around entities, an example of this can be seen by picking up props with the physgun in Garry's Mod 13.

functions.name: Add
functions.description:
Applies a <page>halo</page> glow effect to one or multiple entities.
<warning>Using this function outside of the <page>GM:PreDrawHalos</page> hook can cause instability or crashes.</warning>
<note>The ignoreZ parameter will cause the halos to draw over the player's viewmodel. You can work around this using <page>render.DepthRange</page> in the <page>GM:PreDrawViewModel</page>, <page>GM:PostDrawViewModel</page>, <page>GM:PreDrawPlayerHands</page> and <page>GM:PostDrawPlayerHands</page> hooks.</note>

arguments.name: entities
arguments.description: A table of entities to add the halo effect to.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: The desired color of the halo. See <page>Color</page>.

arguments.name: blurX
arguments.description: The strength of the halo's blur on the x axis.

arguments.name: blurY
arguments.description: The strength of the halo's blur on the y axis.

arguments.name: passes
arguments.description: The number of times the halo should be drawn per frame. **Increasing this may hinder player FPS**.

arguments.name: additive
arguments.description: Sets the render mode of the halo to additive.

arguments.name: ignoreZ
arguments.description: Renders the halo through anything when set to `true`.

functions.name: Render
functions.description: <internal></internal>Renders a halo according to the specified table, only used internally, called from a <page>GM:PostDrawEffects</page> hook added by the halo library.

arguments.name: entry
arguments.description: Table with info about the halo to draw.

functions.name: RenderedEntity
functions.description:
Returns the entity the halo library is currently rendering the halo for.

The main purpose of this function is to be used in <page>ENTITY:Draw</page> in order not to draw certain parts of the entity when the halo is being rendered, so there's no halo around unwanted entity parts, such as lasers, 3D2D displays, etc.

returnValues.description: If set, the currently rendered entity by the halo library.

name: hammer
description: The hammer library.

functions.name: SendCommand
functions.description: Sends command to Hammer, if Hammer is running with the current map loaded.

arguments.name: cmd
arguments.description:
Command to send including arguments

All commands are in the format "command var1 var2 etc"

All commands that pick an entity with x y z , must use the exact position including decimals. i.e. -354.4523 123.4

# List of commands
| Command       | Description   |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| "session_begin mapName mapVersion" | Starts a hammer edit, locking the editor. mapName is the current map without path or suffix, mapVersion is the current version in the .vmf file |
| "session_end" | Ends a hammer edit, unlocking the editor. |
| "map_check_version mapName mapVersion" | This only works after session_begin, so you'd know the right version already and this only returns ok, this function is apparently useless. |
| "entity_create entityClass x y z" | Creates an entity of entityClass at position x y z |
| "entity_delete entityClass x y z" | Deletes an entity of entityClass at position x y z |
| "entity_set_keyvalue entityClass x y z "key" "value"" | Set's the KeyValue pair of an entity of entityClass at x y z. The Key name and Value String must be in quotes. |
| "entity_rotate_incremental entityClass x y z incX incY incZ" | Rotates an entity of entityClass at x y z by incX incY incZ |
| "node_create nodeClass nodeID x y z" | Creates an AI node of nodeClass with nodeID at x y z you should keep nodeID unique or you will have issues |
| "node_delete nodeID" | Deletes node(s) with nodeID, this will delete multiple nodes if they have the same nodeID |
| "nodelink_create startNodeID endNodeID" | Creates a link between AI nodes startNodeID and endNodeID |
| "nodelink_delete startNodeID endNodeID" | Removes a link between AI nodes startNodeID and endNodeID |

returnValues.description:
Returns "ok" if command succeeded otherwise returns "badcommand"

**All changes only happen in hammer, there is *NO* in game representation/feedback**

name: hook
description: The hook library allows you to add hooks called by the game engine, allowing multiple scripts to modify game function.

functions.name: Add
functions.description: Registers a function (or "callback") with the <page>Hook</page> system so that it will be called automatically whenever a specific event (or "hook") occurs.

arguments.name: eventName
arguments.description: The event to hook on to. This can be any <page text="GM">GM_Hooks</page> hook, gameevent after using <page>gameevent.Listen</page>, or custom hook run with <page>hook.Call</page> or <page>hook.Run</page>.

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description:
The unique identifier, usually a string. This can be used elsewhere in the code to replace or remove the hook. The identifier **should** be unique so that you do not accidentally override some other mods hook, unless that's what you are trying to do.

The identifier can be either a <page>string</page>, or a <page>table</page>/object with an IsValid function defined such as an <page>Entity</page> or <page>Panel</page>. <page>number</page>s and <page>boolean</page>s, for example, are not allowed.

If the identifier is a table/object, it will be inserted in front of the other arguments in the callback and the hook will be called as long as it's valid. However, if IsValid( identifier ) returns false when **any** eventName hook is called, the hook will be removed.

arguments.name: func
arguments.description:
The function to be called, arguments given to it depend on the identifier used.
<warning>
Returning any value besides nil from the hook's function will stop other hooks of the same event down the loop from being executed. Only return a value when absolutely necessary and when you know what you are doing.

It WILL break other addons.
</warning>

functions.name: Call
functions.description:
Calls all hooks associated with the given event until one returns something other than `nil`, and then returns that data.

In almost all cases, you should use <page>hook.Run</page> instead - it calls hook.Call internally but supplies the gamemode table by itself, making your code neater.

arguments.name: eventName
arguments.description: The event to call hooks for.

arguments.name: gamemodeTable
arguments.description: If the gamemode is specified, the gamemode hook within will be called, otherwise not.

arguments.name: args
arguments.description: The arguments to be passed to the hooks.

returnValues.description: Return data from called hooks. Limited to **6** return values.

functions.name: GetTable
functions.description: Returns a list of all the hooks registered with <page>hook.Add</page>.

returnValues.description: A table of tables. See below for output example.

functions.name: Remove
functions.description: Removes the hook with the supplied identifier from the given event.

arguments.name: eventName
arguments.description: The event name.

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: The unique identifier of the hook to remove, usually a string.

functions.name: Run
functions.description:
Calls all hooks associated with the given event **until** one returns something other than `nil` and then returns that data. If no hook returns any data, it will try to call the `GAMEMODE:<eventname>`; alternative, if one exists.

This function internally calls <page>hook.Call</page>.

See also: <page>gamemode.Call</page> - same as this, but does not call hooks if the gamemode hasn't defined the function.
</eventname>

arguments.name: eventName
arguments.description: The event to call hooks for.

arguments.name: args
arguments.description: The arguments to be passed to the hooks.

returnValues.description: Return data from called hooks. Limited to **6** return values.

name: http
description: The http library allows either the server or client to communicate with external websites via HTTP, both `GET` (<page>http.Fetch</page>) and `POST` (<page>http.Post</page>) are supported. A more powerful & advanced method can be used via the global <page>Global.HTTP</page> function.

functions.name: Fetch
functions.description:
Launches an asynchronous **GET** request to an HTTP server. Internally calls Global.HTTP. HTTP requests returning a status code >= `400` are still considered a success and will call the Structures/HTTPRequest callback. The Structures/HTTPRequest callback is usually only called on DNS or TCP errors (e.g. the website is unavailable or the domain does not exist). A rough overview of possible Structures/HTTPRequest messages: * `invalid url` - Invalid/empty url ( no request was attempted ) * `invalid request` - Steam HTTP lib failed to create a HTTP request * `error` - OnComplete callback's second argument, `bError`, is `true` * `unsuccessful` - OnComplete's first argument, `pResult->m_bRequestSuccessful`, returned `false` This cannot send or receive multiple headers with the same name. HTTP-requests that respond with a large body may return an `unsuccessful` error. Try using the [Range](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Range) header to download the file in chunks. HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks (such as `192.168.0.1`, or `127.0.0.1`) won't work.
To enable HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks use Command Line Parameters `-allowlocalhttp`. (Dedicated servers only) **Not all headers are allowed in the client realm, here is a list of known blacklisted headers inside the client realm:** ``` host expect content-length proxy-authenticate accept-charset connection accept-encoding origin date ```

arguments.name: url
arguments.description: The URL of the website to fetch.

arguments.name: onSuccess
arguments.description:
Function to be called on success.
<callback>
<arg type="string" name="body"></arg>
<arg type="number" name="size">equal to <page>string.len</page>(body).</arg>
<arg type="table" name="headers"></arg>
<arg type="number" name="code">The HTTP success code.</arg>
</callback>

arguments.name: onFailure
arguments.description:
Function to be called on failure.
<callback>
<arg type="string" name="error">The error message.</arg>
</callback>

arguments.name: headers
arguments.description: KeyValue table for headers.

functions.name: Post
functions.description:
Sends an asynchronous **POST** request to an HTTP server. Internally calls Global.HTTP. HTTP requests returning a status code >= `400` are still considered a success and will call the Structures/HTTPRequest callback. The Structures/HTTPRequest callback is usually only called on DNS or TCP errors (e.g. the website is unavailable or the domain does not exist). This cannot send or receive multiple headers with the same name. HTTP-requests that respond with a large body may return an `unsuccessful` error. Try using the [Range](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Range) header to download the file in chunks. HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks (such as `192.168.0.1`, or `127.0.0.1`) won't work.
To enable HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks use Command Line Parameters `-allowlocalhttp`. (Dedicated servers only)

arguments.name: url
arguments.description: The url to of the website to post.

arguments.name: parameters
arguments.description: The post parameters (x-www-form-urlencoded) to be send to the server. **Keys and values must be strings**.

arguments.name: onSuccess
arguments.description:
Function to be called on success.
<callback>
<arg type="string" name="body">The reponse body as a string.</arg>
<arg type="string" name="size">equal to <page>string.len</page>(body).</arg>
<arg type="table" name="headers">The response headers as a table.</arg>
<arg type="number" name="code">The HTTP success code.</arg>
</callback>

arguments.name: onFailure
arguments.description:
Function to be called on failure.
<callback>
<arg type="string" name="error">The error message.</arg>
</callback>

arguments.name: headers
arguments.description: KeyValue table for headers.

name: input
description: The input library allows you to gather information about the clients input devices (mouse & keyboard), such as the cursor position and whether a key is pressed or not.

functions.name: CheckKeyTrapping
functions.description: Returns the last key captured by key trapping.

functions.name: GetAnalogValue
functions.description: Returns the digital value of an analog stick on the current (set up via convars) controller.

arguments.name: axis
arguments.description: The analog axis to poll. See <page>Enums/ANALOG</page>.

returnValues.description:
The digital value.
<note>A joystick axis returns `-32768` when it's pushed completely up/completely left, & returns `32767` when it's pushed completely down/completely right.

A mouse wheel starts @ `0` & increases by `1` for every unit of scroll up/decreases by `1` for every unit of scroll down.

A mouse axis is `0` when the arrow is @ the top or left of the screen; When the arrow is @ the bottom right of the screen, the mouse y axis is the height of the screen & the mouse x axis is the width of the screen (in pixels). Note that in game, the “arrow” stays near the middle of the screen.

Trigger axis always return `0` (verify).</note>

functions.name: GetCursorPos
functions.description:
Returns the cursor's position on the screen.
<bug issue="4964">On macOS, the cursor isn't locked on the middle of the screen which causes a significant offset of the positions returned by this function.</bug>

returnValues.description: The cursors position on the X axis.
The cursors position on the Y axis.

functions.name: GetKeyCode
functions.description: Gets the button code from a button name. This is opposite of <page>input.GetKeyName</page>.

arguments.name: button
arguments.description: The internal button name, such as <key>E</key> or <key>SHIFT</key>.

functions.name: GetKeyName
functions.description:
Gets the button name from a numeric button code. The name needs to be translated with <page>language.GetPhrase</page> before being displayed.

<note>Despite the name of the function, this also works for the full range of keys in <page>Enums/BUTTON_CODE</page>.</note>

arguments.name: button
arguments.description: The button, see <page>Enums/BUTTON_CODE</page>.

functions.name: IsButtonDown
functions.description:
Gets whether the specified button code is down.

Unlike <page>input.IsKeyDown</page> this can also detect joystick presses from <page>Enums/JOYSTICK</page>

arguments.name: button
arguments.description: The button, valid values are in the range of <page>Enums/BUTTON_CODE</page>.

functions.name: IsControlDown
functions.description: Returns whether a control key is being pressed

returnValues.description: Is Ctrl key down or not

functions.name: IsKeyDown
functions.description: Gets whether a key is down.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key, see <page>Enums/KEY</page>.

functions.name: IsKeyTrapping
functions.description: Returns whether key trapping is activate and the next key press will be captured.

returnValues.description: Whether key trapping active or not

functions.name: IsMouseDown
functions.description: Gets whether a mouse button is down

arguments.name: mouseKey
arguments.description: The key, see <page>Enums/MOUSE</page>

functions.name: IsShiftDown
functions.description: Gets whether a shift key is being pressed

functions.name: LookupBinding
functions.description: Returns the client's bound key for the specified console command. If the player has multiple keys bound to a single command, then the key with the lowest <page>Enums/BUTTON_CODE</page> will be returned.

arguments.name: binding
arguments.description: The binding name

arguments.name: exact
arguments.description: True to disable automatic stripping of a single leading `+` character

returnValues.description:
The first key found with that binding or no value if no key with given binding was found.

See also <page>input.GetKeyCode</page>.

functions.name: LookupKeyBinding
functions.description: Returns the bind string that the given key is bound to.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: Key from <page>Enums/BUTTON_CODE</page>

returnValues.description: The bind string of the given key.

functions.name: SelectWeapon
functions.description: Switches to the provided weapon on the next CUserCmd generation/CreateMove call. Direct binding to [CInput::MakeWeaponSelection](https://github.com/LestaD/SourceEngine2007/blob/43a5c90a5ada1e69ca044595383be67f40b33c61/se2007/game/client/in_main.cpp#L929-L932).

arguments.name: weapon
arguments.description: The weapon entity to switch to.

functions.name: SetCursorPos
functions.description: Sets the cursor's position on the screen, relative to the topleft corner of the window

arguments.name: mouseX
arguments.description: X coordinate for mouse position

arguments.name: mouseY
arguments.description: Y coordinate for mouse position

functions.name: StartKeyTrapping
functions.description: Begins waiting for a key to be pressed so we can save it for <page>input.CheckKeyTrapping</page>. Used by the <page>DBinder</page>.

functions.name: TranslateAlias
functions.description: Translates a console command alias, basically reverse of the `alias` console command.

arguments.name: command
arguments.description: The alias to lookup.

returnValues.description: The command(s) this alias will execute if ran, or nil if the alias doesn't exist.

functions.name: WasKeyPressed
functions.description:
Returns whether a key was initially pressed in the same frame this function was called.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect key presses even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key, see <page>Enums/KEY</page>.

returnValues.description: True if the key was initially pressed the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

functions.name: WasKeyReleased
functions.description:
Returns whether a key was released in the same frame this function was called.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect key releases even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key, see <page>Enums/KEY</page>.

returnValues.description: True if the key was released the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

functions.name: WasKeyTyped
functions.description:
Returns whether the key is being held down or not.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect key events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key to test, see <page>Enums/KEY</page>

returnValues.description: Whether the key is being held down or not.

functions.name: WasMouseDoublePressed
functions.description:
Returns whether a mouse key was double pressed in the same frame this function was called.


If this function returns true, <page>input.WasMousePressed</page> will return false.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect mouse events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

arguments.name: button
arguments.description: The mouse button to test, see <page>Enums/MOUSE</page>

returnValues.description: Whether the mouse key was double pressed or not.

functions.name: WasMousePressed
functions.description:
Returns whether a mouse key was initially pressed in the same frame this function was called.


If <page>input.WasMouseDoublePressed</page> returns true, this function will return false.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect mouse events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key, see <page>Enums/MOUSE</page>

returnValues.description: True if the mouse key was initially pressed the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

functions.name: WasMouseReleased
functions.description:
Returns whether a mouse key was released in the same frame this function was called.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect mouse events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key to test, see <page>Enums/MOUSE</page>

returnValues.description: True if the mouse key was released the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

name: jit
description: Library to work with the [LuaJIT](http://luajit.org/) functionality of gmod.

functions.name: arch
functions.description: A variable containing the target architecture name: `x86`, `x64`, `arm`, `ppc`, `ppcspe`, or `mips`. This will be `x86` or `x64` in GMod.

functions.name: attach

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description:
The callback function.

The arguments passed to the callback depend on the event being reported:

* `"bc"`:
* <page>function</page> **func** - The function that's just been recorded
* `"trace"`:
* <page>string</page> **what** - description of the trace event: "flush", "start", "stop", "abort". Available for all events.
* <page>number</page> **tr** - The trace number. Not available for flush.
* <page>function</page> **func** - The function being traced. Available for start and abort.
* <page>number</page> **pc** - The program counter - the bytecode number of the function being recorded (if this a Lua function). Available for start and abort.
* <page>number</page> **otr** - start: the parent trace number if this is a side trace, abort: abort code
* <page>string</page> **oex** - start: the exit number for the parent trace, abort: abort reason (string)
* `"record"`:
* <page>number</page> **tr** - The trace number. Not available for flush.
* <page>function</page> **func** - The function being traced. Available for start and abort.
* <page>number</page> **pc** - The program counter - the bytecode number of the function being recorded (if this a Lua function). Available for start and abort.
* <page>number</page> **depth** - The depth of the inlining of the current bytecode.
* `"texit"`:
* <page>number</page> **tr** - The trace number. Not available for flush.
* <page>number</page> **ex** - The exit number
* <page>number</page> **ngpr** - The number of general-purpose and floating point registers that are active at the exit.
* <page>number</page> **nfpr** - The number of general-purpose and floating point registers that are active at the exit.

arguments.name: event
arguments.description: The event to hook into.

functions.name: flush
functions.description: Flushes the whole cache of compiled code.

functions.name: off
functions.description: Disables LuaJIT Lua compilation.

functions.name: on
functions.description: Enables LuaJIT Lua compilation.

functions.name: opt.start
functions.description:
JIT compiler optimization control. The opt sub-module provides the backend for the -O command line LuaJIT option.
You can also use it programmatically, e.g.:

```
jit.opt.start(2) -- same as -O2
jit.opt.start("-dce")
jit.opt.start("hotloop=10", "hotexit=2")
```

A list of LuaJIT -O command line options can be found here(a table of various optimization levels are displayed towards the bottom of the page along with exactly which optimization options are enabled for each level): http://luajit.org/running.html

functions.name: os
functions.description: This is NOT a function, it's a variable containing the target OS name: `Windows`, `Linux`, `OSX`, `BSD`, `POSIX` or `Other`.

functions.name: status
functions.description: Returns the status of the JIT compiler and the current optimizations enabled.

returnValues.description: Strings for CPU-specific features and enabled optimizations

functions.name: util.funcbc
functions.description:
Returns bytecode of a function at a position.
<note>This function only works for Lua defined functions.</note>

arguments.name: func
arguments.description: Function to retrieve bytecode from.

arguments.name: pos
arguments.description: Position of the bytecode to retrieve.

functions.name: util.funcinfo
functions.description:
Retrieves LuaJIT information about a given function, similarly to <page>debug.getinfo</page>. Possible table fields:
* linedefined: as for <page>debug.getinfo</page>
* lastlinedefined: as for <page>debug.getinfo</page>
* params: the number of parameters the function takes
* stackslots: the number of stack slots the function's local variable use
* upvalues: the number of upvalues the function uses
* bytecodes: the number of bytecodes it the compiled function
* gcconsts: the number of garbage collectable constants
* nconsts: the number of lua_Number (double) constants
* children: Boolean representing whether the function creates closures
* currentline: as for <page>debug.getinfo</page>
* isvararg: if the function is a vararg function
* source: as for <page>debug.getinfo</page>
* loc: a string describing the source and currentline, like "<source>:<line>"
* ffid: the fast function id of the function (if it is one). In this case only upvalues above and addr below are valid
* addr: the address of the function (if it is not a Lua function). If it's a C function rather than a fast function, only upvalues above is valid*

arguments.name: func
arguments.description: Function or Proto to retrieve info about.

functions.name: util.funck
functions.description:
Gets a constant at a certain index in a function.
<deprecated>This function was disabled due to security concerns.</deprecated>

<warning>This function isn't officially documented on LuaJIT wiki, use it at your own risk.</warning>
<note>Numbers constants goes from 0 (included) to n-1, n being the value of nconsts in <page>jit.util.funcinfo</page> in other words, the consts goes from (nconsts-1) to -n</note>
<note>This function only works for Lua defined functions.</note>

arguments.name: func
arguments.description: Function to get constant from

arguments.name: index
arguments.description: Constant index (counting down from the top of the function at -1)

returnValues.description:
The constant found.

<note>This will return a <page>proto</page> for functions that are created inside the target function - see Example 2.</note>

functions.name: util.funcuvname
functions.description:
<deprecated>This function was disabled due to security concerns.</deprecated>

Does the exact same thing as <page>debug.getupvalue</page> except it only returns the name, not the name and the object. The upvalue indexes also start at 0 rather than 1, so doing `jit.util.funcuvname(func, 0)` will get you the same name as `debug.getupvalue(func, 1)`
<warning>This function isn't officially documented on LuaJIT wiki, use it at your own risk.</warning>

arguments.name: func
arguments.description: Function to get the upvalue indexed from

arguments.name: index
arguments.description: The upvalue index, starting from 0

returnValues.description: The function returns nil if there is no upvalue with the given index, otherwise the name of the upvalue is returned

functions.name: util.ircalladdr
functions.description:
<deprecated>This function was disabled due to security concerns.</deprecated>

functions.name: util.traceinfo
functions.description:
<deprecated>This function was disabled due to security concerns.</deprecated>

Return table fields:
* link (number): the linked trace (0 for link types: none, return, interpreter)
* nk (number): the lowest IR constant (???)
* nins (number): the next IR instruction (???)
* linktype (string): the link type (none, root, loop, tail-recursion, up-recursion, down-recursion, interpreter, return)
* nexit (number): number of snapshots (for use with <page>jit.util.tracesnap</page>)

arguments.name: trace
arguments.description: trace index to retrieve info for (gotten via <page>jit.attach</page>)

functions.name: util.traceir
functions.description: <deprecated>This function was disabled due to security concerns.</deprecated>

functions.name: util.tracemc

functions.name: util.tracesnap
functions.description:
<deprecated>This function was disabled due to security concerns.</deprecated>

Return table fields:
* 0 (ref) (number): first IR ref for the snapshot
* 1 (nslots) (number): the number of valid slots
* all indexes except first 2 and last (there might not be any of these): the snapshot map
* last index in table (number): -16777216 (255 << 24)

arguments.name: tr
arguments.description: trace index to retrieve snapshot for (gotten via <page>jit.attach</page>)

arguments.name: sn
arguments.description: snapshot index for trace (starting from 0 to nexit - 1, nexit gotten via <page>jit.util.traceinfo</page>)

functions.name: version
functions.description: A variable containing the LuaJIT version string. This is `LuaJIT 2.0.4` in GMod, and `LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3` on the x86-64 branch of GMod.

functions.name: version_num
functions.description: A variable containing the version number of the LuaJIT core.

returnValues.description: The version number.  Version `xx.yy.zz` is represented by the decimal number `xxyyzz`. In GMod this is `20004`. On x86-64 branch it's `20100`.

name: killicon
description: The killicon library is used to add to and control the icons that appear in the top right of your screen when a player is killed.

functions.name: Add
functions.description: Creates new kill icon using a texture.

arguments.name: class
arguments.description: Weapon or entity class

arguments.name: texture
arguments.description: Path to the texture

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: Color of the kill icon

functions.name: AddAlias
functions.description: Creates kill icon from existing one.

arguments.name: new_class
arguments.description: New class of the kill icon

arguments.name: existing_class
arguments.description: Already existing kill icon class

functions.name: AddFont
functions.description: Adds kill icon for given weapon/entity class using special font.

arguments.name: class
arguments.description: Weapon or entity class.

arguments.name: font
arguments.description: Font to be used.

arguments.name: symbol
arguments.description: The symbol to be used.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: Color of the killicon.

arguments.name: heightScale
arguments.description: Used internally to correct certain killicons to more closely match their visual size.

functions.name: AddTexCoord
functions.description: Creates new kill icon using a sub-rectangle of a texture.

arguments.name: class
arguments.description: Weapon or entity class this killicon is for.

arguments.name: texture
arguments.description: Path to the texture.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: Color of the kill icon.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The start position (X axis) of the rectangle on the given texture. This is in texture coordinates.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The start position (Y axis) of the rectangle on the given texture. This is in texture coordinates.

arguments.name: w
arguments.description: The width of the rectangle on the given texture. This is in texture coordinates.

arguments.name: h
arguments.description: The height of the rectangle on the given texture. This is in texture coordinates.

functions.name: Draw
functions.description:
Draws a kill icon.

<deprecated>This function applies unpredictable vertical offsets, you should use <page>killicon.Render</page> instead, which does not suffer from this issue.</deprecated>

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: X coordinate of the icon

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Y coordinate of the icon

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Classname of the kill icon

arguments.name: alpha
arguments.description: Alpha/transparency value ( 0 - 255 ) of the icon

functions.name: Exists
functions.description: Checks if kill icon exists for given class.

arguments.name: class
arguments.description: The class to test

returnValues.description: Returns true if kill icon exists

functions.name: GetSize
functions.description: Returns the size of a kill icon.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Classname of the kill icon

arguments.name: dontEqualizeHeight
arguments.description: If set to `true`, returns the real size of the kill icon, without trying to equalize the height to match the default kill icon font.

functions.name: Render
functions.description: Renders a kill icon.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: X coordinate of the icon

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Y coordinate of the icon

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Classname of the kill icon

arguments.name: alpha
arguments.description: Alpha/transparency value ( 0 - 255 ) of the icon

arguments.name: dontEqualizeHeight
arguments.description: Do not rescale the icon to match the default kill icon font.

name: language
description: The language library is used for translation.

functions.name: Add
functions.description: Adds a language item. Language placeholders preceded with "#" are replaced with full text in Garry's Mod once registered with this function.

arguments.name: placeholder
arguments.description: The key for this phrase, without the preceding "#".

arguments.name: fulltext
arguments.description: The phrase that should be displayed whenever this key is used.

functions.name: GetPhrase
functions.description: Retrieves the translated version of inputted string. Useful for concentrating multiple translated strings.

arguments.name: phrase
arguments.description: The phrase to translate

returnValues.description: The translated phrase, or the input string if no translation was found. There is a limit of 4000 bytes for the returned string.

name: list
description: The list library allows you add and retrieve values to and from lists. The list library is basically a fancy wrapper for a table, but with much more limited functionality. See <page>Default Lists</page> for a page of default Sandbox lists.

functions.name: Add
functions.description: Adds an item to a named list

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: The list identifier

arguments.name: item
arguments.description: The item to add to the list

returnValues.description: The index at which the item was added.

functions.name: Contains
functions.description:
Returns true if the list contains the value. (as a value - not a key)

For a function that looks for a key and not a value see <page>list.HasEntry</page>.

arguments.name: list
arguments.description: List to search through

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value to test

returnValues.description: Returns true if the list contains the value, false otherwise

functions.name: Get
functions.description: Returns a copy of the list stored at identifier

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: The list identifier

functions.name: GetForEdit
functions.description: Returns the actual table of the list stored at identifier. Modifying this will affect the stored list

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: The list identifier

arguments.name: dontCreate
arguments.description: If the list at given identifier does not exist, do **not** create it.

functions.name: GetTable
functions.description: Returns a list of all lists currently in use.

returnValues.description: The list of all lists, i.e. a table containing names of all lists.

functions.name: HasEntry
functions.description:
Returns true if the list contains the given key.

For a function that looks for values and not keys see <page>list.Contains</page>.

arguments.name: list
arguments.description: List to search through

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key to test

returnValues.description: Returns true if the list contains the key, false otherwise

functions.name: Set
functions.description: Sets a specific position in the named list to a value.

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: The list identifier

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key in the list to set

arguments.name: item
arguments.description: The item to set to the list as key

name: markup
description: The markup library only contains a single function to create a <page>MarkupObject</page>.

functions.name: Color
functions.description: A convenience function that converts a <page>Color</page> into its markup ready string representation.

arguments.name: col
arguments.description: The <page>Color</page> to convert.

functions.name: Escape
functions.description: Converts a string to its escaped, markup-safe equivalent.

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The string to sanitize.

returnValues.name: sanitizedText
returnValues.description: The parsed markup object ready to be drawn.

functions.name: Parse
functions.description: Parses markup into a <page>MarkupObject</page>. Currently, this only supports fonts and colors as demonstrated in the example.

arguments.name: markup
arguments.description: The markup to be parsed.

arguments.name: maxWidth
arguments.description: The max width of the output

returnValues.description: The parsed markup object ready to be drawn via <page>MarkupObject:Draw</page>.

name: math
description: An easing library that allows you to interpolate with various kinds of smoothing [functions](https://easings.net/). To use with Global.Lerp, input what you would to the fraction argument in one of these easing functions and then the output of that into the Global.Lerp fraction argument. Example usage with Lerp and math.ease.InSine -- Define a wrapper function to make it easier to work with local function easedLerp(fraction, from, to) return Lerp(math.ease.InSine(fraction), from, to) end -- Compare with the non-eased version of Lerp print(easedLerp(0.25, 0, 1)) print(Lerp(0.25, 0, 1)) print(easedLerp(0.25, 0, 5)) print(Lerp(0.25, 0, 5)) ``` 0.076120467488713 0.25 0.38060233744357 1.25 ``` A brief visual example of different easing methods

functions.name: abs
functions.description: Calculates the absolute value of a number (effectively removes any negative sign).

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The number to get the absolute value of.

functions.name: acos
functions.description: Returns the [arccosine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arccosine) of the given number.

arguments.name: cos
arguments.description: Cosine value in range of -1 to 1.

returnValues.description:
An angle in radians, between 0 and pi, which has the given cos value.

<page>nan</page> if the argument is out of range.

functions.name: AngleDifference
functions.description: Calculates the difference between two angles.

arguments.name: a
arguments.description: The first angle.

arguments.name: b
arguments.description: The second angle.

returnValues.description: The difference between the angles between -180 and 180

functions.name: Approach
functions.description: Gradually approaches the target value by the specified amount.

arguments.name: current
arguments.description: The value we're currently at.

arguments.name: target
arguments.description: The target value. This function will never overshoot this value.

arguments.name: change
arguments.description: The amount that the current value is allowed to change by to approach the target. (It makes no difference whether this is positive or negative.)

returnValues.description: New current value, closer to the target than it was previously.

functions.name: ApproachAngle
functions.description:
Increments an angle towards another by specified rate.

<note>This function is for numbers representing angles (0-360), NOT <page>Angle</page> objects!</note>

arguments.name: currentAngle
arguments.description: The current angle to increase

arguments.name: targetAngle
arguments.description: The angle to increase towards

arguments.name: rate
arguments.description: The amount to approach the target angle by

functions.name: asin
functions.description: Returns the [arcsine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_trigonometric_functions) of the given number.

arguments.name: normal
arguments.description: Sine value in the range of -1 to 1.

returnValues.description:
An angle in radians, in the range -pi/2 to pi/2, which has the given sine value.

<page>nan</page> if the argument is out of range.

functions.name: atan
functions.description: Returns the [arctangent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_trigonometric_functions) of the given number.

arguments.name: normal
arguments.description: Tangent value.

returnValues.description: An angle in radians, in the range -pi/2 to pi/2, which has the given tangent.

functions.name: atan2
functions.description:
functions like <page>math.atan</page>(y / x), except it also takes into account the quadrant of the angle and so doesn't have a limited range of output.

<note>The Y argument comes first!</note>

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Y coordinate.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: X coordinate.

returnValues.description: The angle of the line from (0, 0) to (x, y) in radians, in the left-open interval (-pi, pi]

functions.name: BinToInt
functions.description: Converts a binary string into a number.

arguments.name: string
arguments.description: Binary string to convert

functions.name: BSplinePoint
functions.description: Basic code for Bézier-Spline algorithm.

arguments.description: A number in the range `[0,fractionMax]` which controls which location along the spline's length should be evaluated as the return value.

arguments.name: points
arguments.description:
A table of <page text="Vectors">Vector</page> that form the spline.

There must be **at least** 4 points.

arguments.name: fractionMax
arguments.description:
The maximum value of the `fraction` argument.

The most common value for this is `1`.
