functions.name: fmod
functions.description:
Returns the modulus of the specified values.

While this is similar to the `%` operator, **it will return a negative value if the first argument is negative**, whereas the % operator will return a **positive** value **even if the first operand is negative**.

This function is also slower than the `%` operator.

arguments.name: base
arguments.description: The base value.

arguments.name: modulator
arguments.description: The modulator.

functions.name: frexp
functions.description:
**Lua reference description**: Returns `m` and `e` such that `x = m2e`, `e` is an integer and the absolute value of `m` is in the range ((0.5, 1) (or zero when x is zero).

Used to split the number value into a normalized fraction and an exponent. Two values are returned: the first is a multiplier in the range `1/2` (**inclusive**) to `1` (**exclusive**) and the second is an integer exponent.

The result is such that `x = m*2^e`.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The value to get the normalized fraction and the exponent from.

functions.name: huge
functions.description:
A variable that effectively represents infinity, in the sense that in any numerical comparison every number will be less than this.

For example, if `x` is a number, `x > math.huge` will **NEVER** be `true` except in the case of overflow (see below).

Lua will consider any number greater than or equal to `2^1024` (the exponent limit of a [double](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-precision_floating-point_format)) as `inf` and hence equal to this.

functions.name: IntToBin
functions.description: Converts an integer to a binary (base-2) string.

arguments.name: int
arguments.description: Number to be converted.

returnValues.description: Binary number string. The length of this will always be a multiple of 3.

functions.name: IsNearlyEqual
functions.description:
Checks if two floating point numbers are nearly equal.

This is useful to mitigate  [accuracy issues in floating point numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating-point_arithmetic#Accuracy_problems). See examples below.

arguments.name: a
arguments.description: The first number to compare.

arguments.name: b
arguments.description: The second number to compare.

arguments.name: tolerance
arguments.description: The maximum difference between the two numbers to consider them equal.

returnValues.description: True if the difference between the two numbers is less than or equal to the tolerance.

functions.name: ldexp
functions.description:
Takes a normalised number and returns the floating point representation.

Effectively it returns the result of `normalizedFraction * 2.0 ^ exponent`. <page>math.frexp</page> is the opposite function.

arguments.name: normalizedFraction
arguments.description: The value to get the normalized fraction and the exponent from.

arguments.name: exponent
arguments.description: The value to get the normalized fraction and the exponent from.

functions.name: log
functions.description:
With one argument, return the natural logarithm of x (to base e).

With two arguments, return the logarithm of x to the given base, calculated as log(x)/log(base).

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The value to get the base from exponent from.

arguments.name: base
arguments.description: The logarithmic base.

returnValues.description: Logarithm of x to the given base

functions.name: log10
functions.description: Returns the base-10 logarithm of x. This is usually more accurate than math.log(x, 10).

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The value to get the base from exponent from.

functions.name: max
functions.description: Returns the largest value of all arguments.

arguments.name: numbers
arguments.description: Numbers to get the largest from

functions.name: min
functions.description: Returns the smallest value of all arguments.

arguments.name: numbers
arguments.description: Numbers to get the smallest from.

functions.name: mod
functions.description:
<deprecated>This is removed in Lua versions later than what GMod is currently using. You should use the % operator or <page>math.fmod</page> instead.</deprecated>

Returns the modulus of the specified values. Same as <page>math.fmod</page>.

arguments.name: base
arguments.description: The base value

arguments.name: modulator
arguments.description: Modulator

functions.name: modf
functions.description: Returns the integral and fractional component of the modulo operation.

arguments.name: base
arguments.description: The base value.

functions.name: NormalizeAngle
functions.description: Normalizes angle, so it returns value between -180 and 180.

arguments.name: angle
arguments.description: The angle to normalize, in degrees.

returnValues.description: The normalized angle, in the range of -180 to 180 degrees.

functions.name: pi
functions.description:
A variable containing the mathematical constant pi. (`3.1415926535898`)

See also: <page>Trigonometry</page>

<note>It should be noted that due to the nature of floating point numbers, results of calculations with `math.pi` may not be what you expect. See second example below.</note>

functions.name: pow
functions.description:
Returns x raised to the power y.
In particular, math.pow(1.0, x) and math.pow(x, 0.0) always return 1.0, even when x is a zero or a <page>nan</page>. If both x and y are finite, x is negative, and y is not an integer then math.pow(x, y) is undefined.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: Base.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: Exponent.

functions.name: QuadraticBezier
functions.description:
Lerp point between 3 control points with quadratic bezier.

See <page>math.CubicBezier</page> for a function which works with 4 control points.

arguments.name: frac
arguments.description: The fraction for finding the result.

arguments.name: p0
arguments.description: First control point

arguments.name: p1
arguments.description: Tangent

arguments.name: p2
arguments.description: Second control point

returnValues.description: Point between control points at the specified fraction

functions.name: rad
functions.description: Converts an angle in degrees to it's equivalent in radians.

arguments.name: degrees
arguments.description: The angle measured in degrees.

functions.name: Rand
functions.description:
Returns a random float between min and max.

See also <page>math.random</page>

arguments.name: min
arguments.description: The minimum value.

arguments.name: max
arguments.description: The maximum value.

returnValues.description: Random float between min and max.

functions.name: random
functions.description:
When called without arguments, returns a uniform pseudo-random real number in the range 0 to 1 which includes 0 but excludes 1.

When called with an integer number m, returns a uniform pseudo-random integer in the range 1 to m inclusive.

When called with two integer numbers m and n, returns a uniform pseudo-random integer in the range m to n inclusive.

See also <page>math.Rand</page>

arguments.name: m
arguments.description:
If m is the only parameter: upper limit.

If n is also provided: lower limit.

If provided, this must be an integer.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description:
Upper limit.

If provided, this must be an integer.

functions.name: randomseed
functions.description:
Seeds the random number generator. The same seed will guarantee the same sequence of numbers each time with <page>math.random</page>.

For shared random values across predicted realms, use <page>util.SharedRandom</page>.

<warning>Incorrect usage of this function will affect `all` random numbers in the game.</warning>

arguments.name: seed
arguments.description: The new seed

functions.name: Remap
functions.description: Remaps the value from one range to another

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value

arguments.name: inMin
arguments.description: The minimum of the initial range

arguments.name: inMax
arguments.description: The maximum of the initial range

arguments.name: outMin
arguments.description: The minimum of new range

arguments.name: outMax
arguments.description: The maximum of new range

returnValues.description: The number in the new range

functions.name: Round
functions.description: Rounds the given value to the nearest whole number or to the given decimal places.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: The value to round.

arguments.name: decimals
arguments.description: The decimal places to round to.

functions.name: sin
functions.description: Returns the [sine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigonometric_functions) of given angle.

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Angle in radians

returnValues.description: Sine for given angle in the range (-1, 1)

functions.name: sinh
functions.description: Returns the [hyperbolic sine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_functions) of the given angle.

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Angle in radians.

returnValues.description: The hyperbolic sine of the given angle.

functions.name: SnapTo
functions.description: Snaps a number to the closest multiplicative of given number. See also <page>Angle:SnapTo</page>.

arguments.name: input
arguments.description: The number to snap.

arguments.name: snapTo
arguments.description: What to snap the input number to.

functions.name: sqrt
functions.description: Returns the square root of the number.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: Value to get the square root of.

functions.name: tan
functions.description: Returns the tangent of the given angle.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: Angle in radians

returnValues.description: The tangent of the given angle.

functions.name: tanh
functions.description: Returns the [hyperbolic tangent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_functions) of the given number.

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Angle in radians.

returnValues.description: The hyperbolic tangent of the given angle.

functions.name: tau
functions.description:
A variable containing the mathematical constant tau, which is equivalent to 2*<page>math.pi</page>. (`6.28318530718`)

See also: <page>Trigonometry</page>

<note>It should be noted that due to the nature of floating point numbers, results of calculations with `math.tau` may not be what you expect. See the second example on <page>math.pi</page> page.</note>

functions.name: TimeFraction
functions.description: Returns the fraction of where the current time is relative to the start and end times

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: Start time in seconds

arguments.name: end
arguments.description: End time in seconds

arguments.name: current
arguments.description: Current time in seconds

functions.name: Truncate
functions.description: Trim unwanted decimal places.

arguments.name: num
arguments.description: The number to truncate

arguments.name: digits
arguments.description: The amount of digits to keep after the point.

name: matproxy
description:
A library that allows implementing custom [material proxies](https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/Material_proxies) for materials.

Material proxies allow programmatically setting specific `.vmt` shader parameters on a per-entity basis, rather being global across all instances of a material.

functions.name: ActiveList
functions.description: <internal></internal>A list of all **active** material proxies.

returnValues.description: The list of all active material proxies.

functions.name: Add
functions.description:
Register a material proxy. See <page>matproxy</page> for more general explanation of what they are.
<note>The `bind` function is required. The `init` function won't run without it set.</note>

arguments.name: matProxyData
arguments.description: The information about the proxy. See <page>Structures/MatProxyData</page>

functions.name: Call
functions.description:
<internal></internal>
Called by the engine from `OnBind`. Calls <page text="bind">Structures/MatProxyData#bind</page> method of the Lua material proxy.

arguments.name: uname
arguments.description: The material proxy name.

arguments.name: mat
arguments.description: The material the proxy is being applied to.

arguments.name: ent
arguments.description: The entity the material is applied to.

functions.name: Init
functions.description:
<internal></internal>
Called by the engine from `OnBind`. Calls <page text="init">Structures/MatProxyData#init</page> method of the Lua material proxy.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: Name of the material proxy.

arguments.name: uname
arguments.description: Name for the active material proxy instance.

arguments.name: mat
arguments.description: Material the material proxy is applied to.

arguments.name: values
arguments.description: `.vmt` shader parameters of the material.

functions.name: ProxyList
functions.description: A list of all material proxies registered with <page>matproxy.Add</page>.

returnValues.description: The list of all material proxies.

functions.name: ShouldOverrideProxy
functions.description:
<internal></internal>
Called by engine to determine if a certain material proxy is registered in Lua.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: The name of proxy in question

returnValues.description: Whether the material proxy of given name is registered.

name: menu
description: The menu library.

functions.name: RecordFrame
functions.description:
<internal></internal>

Used by "Demo to Video" to record the frame.

name: menubar
description: The menubar library.

functions.name: Init
functions.description:
Creates the menu bar ( The bar at the top of the screen when holding C or Q in sandbox ) and docks it to the top of the screen. It will not appear.


Calling this multiple times will **NOT** remove previous panel.

functions.name: IsParent
functions.description: Checks if the supplied panel is parent to the menubar

arguments.name: pnl
arguments.description: The panel to check

functions.name: ParentTo
functions.description: Parents the menubar to the panel and displays the menubar.

arguments.name: pnl
arguments.description: The panel to parent to

name: mesh
description: The mesh library allows you to create meshes. A mesh is a set of vertices that define a 3D shape, for constant meshes you should use the <page>IMesh</page> object instead.

functions.name: AdvanceVertex
functions.description: Pushes the currently set vertex data (via other `mesh.*` functions) into the mesh stack. See example on <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

functions.name: Begin
functions.description:
<warning>Maximum of 32768 vertices.</warning>
Starts constructing a new 3D mesh constructed from a given number of primitives in a given primitive format.

The resulting mesh can be stored in an <page>IMesh</page> if it is intended to be drawn multiple times or on multiple frames.

arguments.name: primitiveType
arguments.description:
An enum that indicates what the format of the mesh's primitives will be.
For a full list of the available options, see the <page>Enums/MATERIAL</page>.

arguments.name: primitiveCount
arguments.description:
The quantity of primitives this mesh will contain as a whole integer number.

The expected value of this argument is dependent on the primitive type used.
For a full list of the primitive counts expected by each primitive type, see <page>Enums/MATERIAL</page>.

arguments.name: mesh
arguments.description: The <page>IMesh</page> that the created mesh will be stored in.

arguments.name: primitiveType
arguments.description:
An enum that indicates what the format of the mesh's primitives will be.
For a full list of the available options, see the <page>Enums/MATERIAL</page>.

arguments.name: primitiveCount
arguments.description:
The quantity of primitives this mesh will contain as a whole integer number.

The expected value of this argument is dependent on the primitive type used.
For a full list of the primitive counts expected by each primitive type, see <page>Enums/MATERIAL</page>.

functions.name: Color
functions.description: Sets the color to be used for the next vertex. See <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

arguments.name: r
arguments.description: Red component.

arguments.name: g
arguments.description: Green component.

arguments.name: b
arguments.description: Blue component.

arguments.name: a
arguments.description: Alpha component.

functions.name: End
functions.description: Ends the mesh (Started with <page>mesh.Begin</page>) and renders it.

functions.name: Normal
functions.description: Sets the normal to be used for the next vertex. See <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

arguments.name: normal
arguments.description: The normal of the vertex.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X part of the vertex normal.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y part of the vertex normal.

arguments.name: z
arguments.description: The Z part of the vertex normal.

functions.name: Position
functions.description: Sets the position to be used for the next vertex. See <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

arguments.name: position
arguments.description: The position of the vertex.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X position of the vertex.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y position of the vertex.

arguments.name: z
arguments.description: The Z position of the vertex.

functions.name: Quad
functions.description: Adds a quad (4 vertices) to the currently built mesh. See <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

arguments.name: vertex1
arguments.description: The first vertex.

arguments.name: vertex2
arguments.description: The second vertex.

arguments.name: vertex3
arguments.description: The third vertex.

arguments.name: vertex4
arguments.description: The fourth vertex.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: The color for the vertices.

functions.name: QuadEasy
functions.description:
Adds a quad (4 vertices) to the currently built mesh, by using position, normal and sizes. See <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

See also <page>mesh.Quad</page>.

arguments.name: position
arguments.description: The center of the quad.

arguments.name: normal
arguments.description: The normal of the quad.

arguments.name: sizeX
arguments.description: X size in pixels.

arguments.name: sizeY
arguments.description: Y size in pixels.

arguments.name: color
arguments.description: The color for the vertices.

functions.name: Specular
functions.description:
Sets the specular map values.

There is no known use case for this function.

arguments.name: r
arguments.description: The red channel multiplier of the specular map.

arguments.name: g
arguments.description: The green channel multiplier of the specular map.

arguments.name: b
arguments.description: The blue channel multiplier of the specular map.

arguments.name: a
arguments.description: The alpha channel multiplier of the specular map.

functions.name: TangentS
functions.description:
Sets the `S` tangent to be used, also known as "binormal".

Tangents and binormals are using in bumpmap rendering.

See also <page>mesh.TangentT</page> and <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

arguments.name: tangentS
arguments.description: The S tangent.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X part of the vertex' tangent S.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y part of the vertex' tangent S.

arguments.name: z
arguments.description: The Z part of the vertex' tangent S.

functions.name: TangentT
functions.description:
Sets the `T` tangent to be used.

Tangents and binormals are using in bumpmap rendering.

See also <page>mesh.TangentS</page> and <page>mesh.Begin</page>.

arguments.name: tangentT
arguments.description: The T tangent.

arguments.name: x
arguments.description: The X part of the vertex' tangent T.

arguments.name: y
arguments.description: The Y part of the vertex' tangent T.

arguments.name: z
arguments.description: The Z part of the vertex' tangent T.

functions.name: TexCoord
functions.description: Sets the texture coordinates for the next vertex.

arguments.name: set
arguments.description:
The texture coordinate set, 0 to 7.

Non-zero values require the currently bound material to support it. For example, any `LightmappedGeneric` material supports sets 1 and 2 (lightmap texture coordinates and bump map texture coords?).

arguments.name: u
arguments.description: U coordinate.

arguments.name: v
arguments.description: V coordinate.

functions.name: UserData
functions.description:
A set of four numbers that can be used for arbitrary purposes by <page>Material</page> shaders.
This is most commonly used to provide tangent information about each vertex to the Material's shader.

functions.name: VertexCount
functions.description: Returns the amount of vertices that have been pushed via <page>mesh.AdvanceVertex</page>.

name: motionsensor
description:
Functions related to Kinect for Windows usage in GMod.
<warning>Kinect feature works only on 32-bit version of the game.</warning>

functions.name: BuildSkeleton
functions.description: <internal></internal> Called to build the skeleton. See <page>Using The Kinect</page> and <page>Kinect developing</page>.

arguments.name: translator
arguments.description: `list.Get( "SkeletonConvertor" )` and <page>motionsensor.ChooseBuilderFromEntity</page>.

arguments.name: player
arguments.description: The player to get motion sensor positions from.

arguments.name: rotation
arguments.description: Global rotation of the player?

arguments.name: ent
arguments.description: Entity to choose builder for

returnValues.description: Chosen builder. The builders are stored in `list.Get( "SkeletonConvertor" )`

functions.name: GetColourMaterial
functions.description: Returns the depth map material.

functions.name: GetSkeleton
functions.description: Returns players skeletal data if they are using Kinect. See <page>Using The Kinect</page> and <page>Kinect developing</page>.

functions.name: IsActive
functions.description: Return whether a kinect is connected - and active (ie - Start has been called).

functions.name: IsAvailable
functions.description: Returns true if we have detected that there's a kinect connected to the PC

functions.name: ProcessAngle
functions.description: <internal></internal> Used internally by <page>motionsensor.ProcessAnglesTable</page>. See <page>Using The Kinect</page> and <page>Kinect developing</page>.

functions.name: ProcessAnglesTable
functions.description: <internal></internal> Used internally by <page>motionsensor.BuildSkeleton</page>. See <page>Using The Kinect</page> and <page>Kinect developing</page>.

functions.name: ProcessPositionTable
functions.description: <internal></internal> Used internally by <page>motionsensor.BuildSkeleton</page>. See <page>Using The Kinect</page> and <page>Kinect developing</page>.

functions.name: Start
functions.description: This starts access to the kinect sensor. Note that this usually freezes the game for a couple of seconds.

returnValues.description: `true` if the access has been started

functions.name: Stop
functions.description: Stops the motion capture.

name: navmesh
description:
The navigation mesh library. To be used with <page>CNavArea</page>.

The navigation mesh is used by <page>NextBot</page> to calculate path to its target.

functions.name: AddWalkableSeed
functions.description: Add this position and normal to the list of walkable positions, used before map generation with <page>navmesh.BeginGeneration</page>

arguments.name: pos
arguments.description: The terrain position.

arguments.name: dir
arguments.description: The normal of this terrain position.

functions.name: BeginGeneration
functions.description:
Starts the generation of a new navmesh.

<note>This process is highly resource intensive and it's not wise to use during normal gameplay</note>

functions.name: ClearWalkableSeeds
functions.description: Clears all the walkable positions, used before calling <page>navmesh.BeginGeneration</page>.

functions.name: CreateNavArea
functions.description: Creates a new <page>CNavArea</page>.

arguments.name: corner
arguments.description: The first corner of the new <page>CNavArea</page>

arguments.name: opposite_corner
arguments.description: The opposite (diagonally) corner of the new <page>CNavArea</page>

returnValues.description: The new <page>CNavArea</page> or <page>nil</page> if we failed for some reason.

functions.name: CreateNavLadder
functions.description: Creates a new <page>CNavLadder</page>.

arguments.name: top
arguments.description: The top position of the ladder.

arguments.name: bottom
arguments.description: The bottom position of the ladder.

arguments.name: width
arguments.description: Width for the new ladder.

arguments.name: dir
arguments.description: Directional vector in which way the ladder should be facing. Please note that ladders can only face in the 4 cardinal directions - NORTH, SOUTH, WEST, EAST.

arguments.name: maxHeightAboveTopArea
arguments.description: If above 0, will limit how much the top of the ladder can be adjusted to the closest <page>CNavArea</page> when automatically connecting the newly created ladder to pre-existing nav areas.

returnValues.description: The new <page>CNavLadder</page> or <page>nil</page> if we failed for some reason.

functions.name: Find
functions.description: Returns a list of areas within distance, used to find hiding spots by <page>NextBot</page>s for example.

arguments.name: pos
arguments.description: The position to search around. This position will be used to find the closest area to search from.

arguments.name: radius
arguments.description: Radius to search within

arguments.name: stepHeight
arguments.description: Maximum step up height allowed

arguments.name: dropHeight
arguments.description: Maximum step down (fall distance) allowed

functions.name: FindInBox
functions.description: Returns a list of <page>CNavArea</page>s overlapping the given cube extents.

arguments.name: pos1
arguments.description: The start position of the cube to search in.

arguments.name: pos2
arguments.description: The "end" position of the cube to search in. This is the opposite corner of the cube, diagonally.

functions.name: GetAllNavAreas
functions.description: Returns an integer indexed table of all <page>CNavArea</page>s on the current map. If the map doesn't have a navmesh generated then this will return an empty table.

returnValues.description: A table of all the <page>CNavArea</page>s on the current map.

functions.name: GetBlockedAreas
functions.description: Returns a table of all blocked <page>CNavArea</page>s on the current map. See <page>CNavArea:MarkAsBlocked</page>.

returnValues.description: A table of all the blocked <page>CNavArea</page>s on the current map.

functions.name: GetEditCursorPosition
functions.description: Returns the position of the edit cursor when nav_edit is set to 1.

returnValues.description: The position of the edit cursor.

functions.name: GetGroundHeight
functions.description:
Finds the closest standable ground at, above, or below the provided position.

<note>The ground must have at least 32 units of empty space above it to be considered by this function, unless 16 layers are tested without finding valid ground.</note>

arguments.name: pos
arguments.description: Position to find the closest ground for.

returnValues.description: The height of the ground layer.
The normal of the ground layer.

functions.name: GetMarkedArea
functions.description: Returns the currently marked <page>CNavArea</page>, for use with editing console commands.

functions.name: GetMarkedLadder
functions.description: Returns the currently marked <page>CNavLadder</page>, for use with editing console commands.

functions.name: GetNavArea
functions.description:
Returns the Nav Area contained in this position that also satisfies the elevation limit.

This function will properly see blocked <page>CNavArea</page>s. See <page>navmesh.GetNearestNavArea</page>.

arguments.name: pos
arguments.description: The position to search for.

arguments.name: beneathLimit
arguments.description: The elevation limit at which the Nav Area will be searched.

functions.name: GetNavAreaByID
functions.description:
Returns a <page>CNavArea</page> by the given ID.

<note>Avoid calling this function every frame, as internally it does a lookup trough all the <page>CNavArea</page>s, call this once and store the result</note>

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: ID of the <page>CNavArea</page> to get. Starts with 1.

functions.name: GetNavAreaCount
functions.description: Returns the total count of nav areas on the map. If you want to get all nav areas, use <page>navmesh.GetAllNavAreas</page> instead as nav areas IDs are not always sequential.

returnValues.description: The total count of nav areas on the map.

functions.name: GetNavLadderByID
functions.description: Returns a <page>CNavLadder</page> by the given ID.

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: ID of the <page>CNavLadder</page> to get. Starts with 1.

functions.name: GetNearestNavArea
functions.description:
Returns the closest <page>CNavArea</page> to given position at the same height, or beneath it.

This function will ignore blocked <page>CNavArea</page>s. See <page>navmesh.GetNavArea</page> for a function that does see blocked areas.

arguments.name: pos
arguments.description: The position to look from

arguments.name: anyZ
arguments.description: This argument is ignored and has no effect

arguments.name: maxDist
arguments.description: This is the maximum distance from the given position that the function will look for a <page>CNavArea</page>

arguments.name: checkLOS
arguments.description:
If this is set to true then the function will internally do a <page>util.TraceLine</page> from the starting position to each potential <page>CNavArea</page> with a [MASK_NPCSOLID_BRUSHONLY](https://wiki.facepunch.com/gmod/Enums/MASK). If the trace fails then the <page>CNavArea</page> is ignored.

If this is set to false then the function will find the closest <page>CNavArea</page> through anything, including the world.

arguments.name: checkGround
arguments.description: If checkGround is true then this function will internally call <page>navmesh.GetNavArea</page> to check if there is a <page>CNavArea</page> directly below the position, and return it if so, before checking anywhere else.

arguments.name: team
arguments.description: This will internally call <page>CNavArea:IsBlocked</page> to check if the target <page>CNavArea</page> is not to be navigated by the given team. Currently this appears to do nothing.

returnValues.description: The closest <page>CNavArea</page> found with the given parameters, or a NULL <page>CNavArea</page> if one was not found.

functions.name: GetPlayerSpawnName
functions.description: Returns the classname of the player spawn entity.

returnValues.description: The classname of the spawn point entity. By default returns "info_player_start"

functions.name: IsGenerating
functions.description: Whether we're currently generating a new navmesh with <page>navmesh.BeginGeneration</page>.

returnValues.description: Whether we're generating a nav mesh or not.

functions.name: IsLoaded
functions.description: Returns true if a navmesh has been loaded when loading the map.

returnValues.description: Whether a navmesh has been loaded when loading the map.

functions.name: Load
functions.description:
Loads a new navmesh from the .nav file for current map discarding any changes made to the navmesh previously.
<warning>
Calling this function too soon, causes the Server to crash!
</warning>

functions.name: Reset
functions.description: Deletes every <page>CNavArea</page> and <page>CNavLadder</page> on the map **without saving the changes**.

functions.name: Save
functions.description: Saves any changes made to navmesh to the .nav file.

functions.name: SetMarkedArea
functions.description: Sets the <page>CNavArea</page> as marked, so it can be used with editing console commands.

arguments.name: area
arguments.description: The <page>CNavArea</page> to set as the marked area.

functions.name: SetMarkedLadder
functions.description: Sets the <page>CNavLadder</page> as marked, so it can be used with editing console commands.

arguments.name: area
arguments.description: The <page>CNavLadder</page> to set as the marked ladder.

functions.name: SetPlayerSpawnName
functions.description: Sets the classname of the default spawn point entity, used before generating a new navmesh with <page>navmesh.BeginGeneration</page>.

arguments.name: spawnPointClass
arguments.description: The classname of what the player uses to spawn, automatically adds it to the walkable positions during map generation.

name: net
description:
The net library is one of a number of ways to send data between the client and server.

The major advantages of the net library are the large size limit (64kb/message) and the ability to send data backwards - from the client to the server.

Refer to <page>Net Library Usage</page> for a short introduction.

functions.name: Abort
functions.description: Cancels a net message started by <page>net.Start</page>, so you can immediately start a new one without any errors.

functions.name: Broadcast
functions.description:
Sends the currently built net message (see <page>net.Start</page>) to all connected players.
More information can be found in <page>Net Library Usage</page>.

functions.name: BytesLeft
functions.description:
Returns the amount of data left to read in the current message. Does nothing when sending data.

<note>This will include 6 extra bits (or 1 byte rounded-up) used by the engine internally.</note>

returnValues.description:
The amount of data left to read in the current net message in **bytes**.
Returns `nil` if no net message has been started.

The amount of data left to read in the current net message in **bits**.
Returns `nil` if no net message has been started.

functions.name: BytesWritten
functions.description:
Returns the size of the current message.

<note>This will include 3 extra bytes (24 bits) used by the engine internally to send the data over the network.</note>

returnValues.description:
The amount of **bytes** written to the current net message.
Returns `nil` if no net message has been started.

The amount of **bits** written to the current net message.
Returns `nil` if no net message has been started.

functions.name: Incoming
functions.description:
<internal>You may be looking for <page>net.Receive</page>.</internal>

Function called by the engine to tell the Lua state a message arrived.

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: The message length, in **bits**.

arguments.name: client
arguments.description: The player that sent the message. This will be `nil` in the client state.

functions.name: ReadAngle
functions.description:
Reads an angle from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The read angle, or `Angle( 0, 0, 0 )` if no angle could be read

functions.name: ReadBit
functions.description:
Reads a bit from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: `0` or `1`, or `0` if the bit could not be read.

functions.name: ReadBool
functions.description:
Reads a boolean from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: `true` or `false`, or `false` if the bool could not be read.

functions.name: ReadColor
functions.description:
Reads a <page>Color</page> from the current net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

arguments.name: hasAlpha
arguments.description: If the color has alpha written or not. **Must match what was given to <page>net.WriteColor</page>.**

returnValues.description: The <page>Color</page> read from the current net message, or `Color( 0, 0, 0, 0 )` if the color could not be read.

functions.name: ReadData
functions.description:
Reads pure binary data from the message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: The length of the data to be read, in **bytes**.

returnValues.description: The binary data read, or a string containing one character with a byte of `0` if no data could be read.

functions.name: ReadDouble
functions.description:
Reads a double-precision number from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The double-precision number, or `0` if no number could be read.

functions.name: ReadEntity
functions.description:
Reads an entity from the received net message. You should always check if the specified entity exists as it may have been removed and therefore `NULL` if it is outside of the players [PVS (Potential Visibility Set)](https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/PVS "PVS - Valve Developer Community") or was already removed.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The entity, or `nil` if no entity could be read.

functions.name: ReadFloat
functions.description:
Reads a floating point number from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The floating point number, or `0` if no number could be read.

functions.name: ReadHeader
functions.description:
<internal></internal>

Reads a word, basically unsigned short. This is used internally to read the "header" of the message which is an unsigned short which can be converted to the corresponding message name via <page>util.NetworkIDToString</page>.

functions.name: ReadInt
functions.description:
Reads an integer from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

arguments.name: bitCount
arguments.description:
The amount of bits to be read.

This must be set to what you set to <page>net.WriteInt</page>. Read more information at <page>net.WriteInt</page>.

returnValues.description: The read integer number, or `0` if no integer could be read.

functions.name: ReadMatrix
functions.description:
Reads a <page>VMatrix</page> from the received net message.
<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The matrix, or an empty matrix if no matrix could be read.

functions.name: ReadNormal
functions.description:
Reads a normal vector from the net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The normalized vector ( length = `1` ), or `Vector( 0, 0, 1 )` if no normal could be read.

functions.name: ReadPlayer
functions.description:
Reads a player entity that was written with <page>net.WritePlayer</page> from the received net message.

You should always check if the specified entity exists as it may have been removed and therefore `NULL` if it is outside of the local players [PVS](https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/PVS) or was already removed.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The player, or `nil` if no entity could be read.

functions.name: ReadString
functions.description:
Reads a [null-terminated string](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null-terminated_string) from the net stream. The size of the string is 8 bits plus 8 bits for every ASCII character in the string.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The read string, or a string with `0` length if no string could be read.

functions.name: ReadTable
functions.description:
Reads a table from the received net message.

See <page>net.WriteTable</page> for extra info.

<note>Sometimes when sending a table through the net library, the order of the keys may be switched. So be cautious when comparing (See example 1).

You may get `net.ReadType: Couldn't read type X` during the execution of the function, the problem is that you are sending objects that **cannot** be serialized/sent over the network.
</note>

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

arguments.name: sequential
arguments.description: Set to `true` if the input table is sequential. This saves on bandwidth.

returnValues.description: Table received via the net message, or a blank table if no table could be read.

functions.name: ReadType
functions.description:
<internal>Used internally by <page>net.ReadTable</page>.</internal>

Reads a value from the net message with the specified type, written by <page>net.WriteType</page>.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

arguments.name: typeID
arguments.description: The type of value to be read, using <page>Enums/TYPE</page>.

returnValues.description: The value, or the respective blank value based on the type you're reading if the value could not be read.

functions.name: ReadUInt
functions.description:
Reads an unsigned integer with the specified number of bits from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

arguments.name: bitCount
arguments.description:
The size of the integer to be read, in bits.

This must be set to what you set to <page>net.WriteUInt</page>. Read more information at <page>net.WriteUInt</page>.

returnValues.description: The unsigned integer read, or `0` if the integer could not be read.

functions.name: ReadUInt64
functions.description:
Reads a unsigned integer with 64 bits from the received net message.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description:
The uint64 number.

<note>Since Lua cannot store full 64-bit integers, this function returns a string. It is mainly aimed at usage with <page>Player:SteamID64</page>.</note>

functions.name: ReadVars
functions.description:
<internal></internal>

A list of types that can be sent over the network via <page>net.ReadType</page>.

returnValues.description: Key = type ID (<page>Global.TypeID</page>), Value = function to send the data over the net.

functions.name: ReadVector
functions.description:
Reads a vector from the received net message. Vectors sent by this function are **compressed**, which may result in precision loss. See <page>net.WriteVector</page> for more information.

<warning>You **must** read information in same order as you write it.</warning>

returnValues.description: The read vector, or `Vector( 0, 0, 0 )` if no vector could be read.

functions.name: Receive
functions.description:
Adds a net message handler. Only one receiver can be used to receive the net message.

You can use the `net.Read*` functions within the message handler callback.

<warning>You **should** put this function **outside** of any other function or hook for it to work properly unless you know what you are doing!

You **must** read information in the same order as you write it.

Each net message has a length limit of **64KB**!</warning>

arguments.name: messageName
arguments.description:
The message name to hook to.

<note>The message-name is converted to lower-case so the message-names "`BigBlue`" and "`bigblue`" would be equal.</note>

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description:
The function to be called if the specified message was received.

<callback>
<arg type="number" name="len">Length of the message, in bits.</arg>
<arg type="Player" name="ply">The player that sent the message, works **only** server-side.</arg>
</callback>

functions.name: Receivers
functions.description:
<internal></internal>

This is NOT a function, it's a table used internally by the net library to store net receivers added with <page>net.Receive</page>.

The key is the lowercase net message name and the value is the message's callback function.

<note>Modifying <page>net.Receivers</page> won't affect the net string pool used in <page>util.AddNetworkString</page>.</note>

returnValues.description: The list of all registered derma controls.

functions.name: Send
functions.description: Sends the current net message to the specified player(s)

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player to send the message to.

arguments.name: plys
arguments.description: A table of players to send the message to.

arguments.name: filter
arguments.description: A recipient filter specifying message targets.

functions.name: SendOmit
functions.description: Sends the current message (see <page>net.Start</page>) to all except the player or players specified.

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player to **NOT** send the message to.

arguments.name: plys
arguments.description: A table of players to **NOT** send the message to.

functions.name: SendPAS
functions.description: Sends current net message (see <page>net.Start</page>) to all players that are in the same [Potentially Audible Set (PAS)](https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/PAS) as the position, or simply said, it adds all players that can potentially hear sounds from this position.

arguments.name: position
arguments.description: PAS position.

functions.name: SendPVS
functions.description: Sends current net message (see <page>net.Start</page>) to all players in the [PVS (Potential Visibility Set)](https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/PVS "PVS - Valve Developer Community") of the position, or, more simply said, sends the message to players that can potentially see this position.

arguments.name: position
arguments.description: Position that must be in players' visibility set.

functions.name: SendToServer
functions.description:
Sends the current net message (see <page>net.Start</page>) to the server. The player object must exist on the server for the net message to be received successfully by the server.

<warning>Each net message has a length limit of 65,533 bytes (approximately 64 KiB) and your net message will error and fail to send if it is larger than this.

The message name must be pooled with <page>util.AddNetworkString</page> beforehand!</warning>

functions.name: Start
functions.description:
Begins a new net message. If another net message is already started and hasn't been sent yet, it will be discarded.

After calling this function, you will want to call `net.Write` functions to write your data, if any, and then finish with a call to one of the following functions:
* <page>net.Send</page>
* <page>net.SendOmit</page>
* <page>net.SendPAS</page>
* <page>net.SendPVS</page>
* <page>net.Broadcast</page>
* <page>net.SendToServer</page>


<warning>Each net message has a length limit of 65,533 bytes (approximately 64 KiB) and your net message will error and fail to send if it is larger than this.

The net library has an internal buffer that sent messages are added to that is capable of holding roughly 256 kb at a time. Trying to send more will lead to the client being kicked because of a buffer overflow. <page text="More information on net library limits can be found here.">Networking_Usage#netlimits</page>

The message name must be pooled with <page>util.AddNetworkString</page> beforehand!

Net messages will not reliably reach the client until the client's <page>GM:InitPostEntity</page> hook is called.</warning>

arguments.name: messageName
arguments.description: The name of the message to send

arguments.name: unreliable
arguments.description: If set to `true`, the message is not guaranteed to reach its destination

returnValues.description: `true` if the message has been started.

functions.name: WriteAngle
functions.description: Writes an angle to the current net message.

arguments.name: angle
arguments.description: The angle to be sent.

functions.name: WriteBit
functions.description:
Appends a boolean (as `1` or `0`) to the current net message.

Please note that the bit is written here from a <page>boolean</page> (`true/false`) but <page>net.ReadBit</page> returns a number.

arguments.name: boolean
arguments.description: Bit status (false = `0`, true = `1`).

functions.name: WriteBool
functions.description: Appends a boolean to the current net message. Alias of <page>net.WriteBit</page>.

arguments.name: boolean
arguments.description: Boolean value to write.

functions.name: WriteColor
functions.description: Appends a <page>Color</page> to the current net message.

arguments.name: Color
arguments.description: The <page>Color</page> you want to append to the net message.

arguments.name: writeAlpha
arguments.description: If we should write the alpha of the color or not.

functions.name: WriteData
functions.description: Writes a chunk of binary data to the message.

arguments.name: binaryData
arguments.description: The binary data to be sent.

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: The length of the binary data to be sent, in bytes.

functions.name: WriteDouble
functions.description: Appends a double-precision number to the current net message.

arguments.name: double
arguments.description: The double to be sent

functions.name: WriteEntity
functions.description:
Appends an entity to the current net message using its <page>Entity:EntIndex</page>.

See <page>net.ReadEntity</page> for the function to read the entity.

arguments.name: entity
arguments.description: The entity to be sent.

functions.name: WriteFloat
functions.description: Appends a float (number with decimals) to the current net message.

arguments.name: float
arguments.description: The float to be sent.

functions.name: WriteInt
functions.description:
Appends a signed integer - a whole number, positive/negative - to the current net message. Can be read back with <page>net.ReadInt</page> on the receiving end.

Use <page>net.WriteUInt</page> to send an unsigned number (that you know will **never** be negative). Use <page>net.WriteFloat</page> for a non-whole number (e.g. `2.25`).

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: The integer to be sent.

functions.name: WriteMatrix
functions.description: Writes a <page>VMatrix</page> to the current net message.

arguments.name: matrix
arguments.description: The matrix to be sent.

functions.name: WriteNormal
functions.description:
Writes a normalized/direction vector ( Vector with length of 1 ) to the net message.

This function uses less bandwidth compared to <page>net.WriteVector</page> and will not send vectors with length of > 1 properly.

arguments.name: normal
arguments.description: The normalized/direction vector to be send.

functions.name: WritePlayer
functions.description:
Appends a player entity to the current net message using its <page>Entity:EntIndex</page>. This saves a small amount of network bandwidth over <page>net.WriteEntity</page>.

See <page>net.ReadPlayer</page> for the function to read the entity.

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player to be sent.

functions.name: WriteString
functions.description:
Appends a string to the current net message. The size of the written data is 8 bits for every ASCII character in the string + 8 bits for the null terminator.

The maximum allowed length of a single written string is **65532 characters**. (aka the limit of the net message itself)

arguments.name: string
arguments.description:
The string to be sent.

The input will be terminated at the first null byte if one is present. See <page>net.WriteData</page> if you wish to write binary data.

functions.name: WriteTable
functions.description:
Appends a table to the current net message. Adds **16 extra bits** per key/value pair, so you're better off writing each individual key/value as the exact type if possible.

<warning>All net messages have a **64kb** buffer. This function will not check or error when that buffer is overflown. You might want to consider using <page>util.TableToJSON</page> and <page>util.Compress</page> and send the resulting string in **60kb** chunks, doing the opposite on the receiving end.</warning>

arguments.name: table
arguments.description:
The table to be sent.

<warning>If the table contains a `nil` key the table may not be read correctly.

Not all objects can be sent over the network. Things like functions, <page>IMaterial</page>s, etc will cause errors when reading the table from a net message.

Each element is also limited by the constraint of the `net.Write<luatype>` function for the element type.</luatype></warning>

arguments.name: sequential
arguments.description:
Set to `true` if the input table is sequential. This saves on bandwidth, adding **8 extra bits** per key/value pair instead of 16 bits.

<note>To read the table you need to give <page>net.ReadTable</page> the same value!</note>

functions.name: WriteType
functions.description:
<internal>Used internally by <page>net.WriteTable</page>.</internal>

Appends any type of value to the current net message.

<note>An additional 8-bit unsigned integer indicating the type will automatically be written to the packet before the value, in order to facilitate reading with <page>net.ReadType</page>. If you know the data type you are writing, use a function meant for that specific data type to reduce amount of data sent.</note>

arguments.name: Data
arguments.description: The data to be sent.

functions.name: WriteUInt
functions.description:
Appends an unsigned integer with the specified number of bits to the current net message.

Use <page>net.WriteInt</page> if you want to send negative and positive numbers. Use <page>net.WriteFloat</page> for a non-whole number (e.g. `2.25`).

<note>Unsigned numbers **do not** support negative numbers.</note>

arguments.name: unsignedInteger
arguments.description: The unsigned integer to be sent.

functions.name: WriteUInt64
functions.description:
Appends an unsigned integer with 64 bits to the current net message.

The limit for an uint64 is 18'446'744'073'709'551'615.
Everything above the limit will be set to the limit.

Unsigned numbers **do not** support negative numbers.

arguments.name: uint64
arguments.description:
The 64 bit value to be sent. Can be a number.
<warning>
Since Lua cannot store full 64-bit integers, this function takes a string. It is mainly aimed at usage with <page>Player:SteamID64</page>.

If your input is a number and not a string, it won't be networked correctly as soon as it has more than 13 digits.
This is because Lua represents numbers over 13 digits as `1e+14`(`100 000 000 000 000`)
You can do something like this to convert it to a string: `string.format("%.0f", number)`.
If you try to use <page>Global.tostring</page> it will fail because it will create a result something like `1e+14` which doesn't work.
</warning>

functions.name: WriteVars
functions.description:
<internal></internal>

A list of types that can be sent over the network via <page>net.WriteType</page>.

returnValues.description: Key = type ID (<page>Global.TypeID</page>), Value = function to send the data over the net.

functions.name: WriteVector
functions.description:
Appends a vector to the current net message.
Vectors sent by this function are compressed, which may result in precision loss. XYZ components greater than `16384` or less than `-16384` are irrecoverably altered (most significant bits are trimmed) and precision after the decimal point is low.

arguments.name: vector
arguments.description: The vector to be sent.

name: notification
description: Used to display notifications on the screen (mid-right).

functions.name: AddLegacy
functions.description: Adds a standard notification to your screen.

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: The text to display.

arguments.name: type
arguments.description: Determines the notification method (e.g. icon) for displaying the notification. See the <page>Enums/NOTIFY</page>.

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: The number of seconds to display the notification for.

functions.name: AddProgress
functions.description: Adds a notification with an animated progress bar.

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: Can be any type. It's used as an index.

arguments.name: strText
arguments.description: The text to show

arguments.name: frac
arguments.description: If set, overrides the progress bar animation with given percentage. Range is 0 to 1.

functions.name: Kill
functions.description: Removes the notification after 0.8 seconds.

arguments.name: uid
arguments.description: The unique ID of the notification

name: numpad
description: The numpad module allows you to execute functions on a key press or release.

functions.name: Activate
functions.description: Activates numpad key owned by the player

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player whose numpad should be simulated

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key to press, see <page>Enums/KEY</page>

arguments.name: isButton
arguments.description: Should this keypress pretend to be a from a `gmod_button`? (causes <page>numpad.FromButton</page> to return `true`)

functions.name: Deactivate
functions.description: Deactivates numpad key owned by the player

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player whose numpad should be simulated

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key to press, corresponding to <page>Enums/KEY</page>

arguments.name: isButton
arguments.description: Should this keypress pretend to be a from a `gmod_button`? (causes <page>numpad.FromButton</page> to return `true`)

functions.name: FromButton
functions.description:
Returns true during a function added with <page>numpad.Register</page> when the third argument to <page>numpad.Activate</page> is true.

This is caused when a numpad function is triggered by a button SENT being used.

functions.name: OnDown
functions.description:
Calls a function registered with <page>numpad.Register</page> when a player presses specified key.

See for key released action: <page>numpad.OnUp</page>

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player whose numpad should be watched

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key, corresponding to <page>Enums/KEY</page>

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: The name of the function to run, corresponding with the one used in <page>numpad.Register</page>
Arguments to pass to the function passed to <page>numpad.Register</page>.

functions.name: OnUp
functions.description:
Calls a function registered with <page>numpad.Register</page> when a player releases specified key.

See for key pressed action: <page>numpad.OnDown</page>

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player whose numpad should be watched

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key, corresponding to <page>Enums/KEY</page>

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: The name of the function to run, corresponding with the one used in <page>numpad.Register</page>
Arguments to pass to the function passed to <page>numpad.Register</page>.

functions.name: Register
functions.description: Registers a numpad library action for use with <page>numpad.OnDown</page> and <page>numpad.OnUp</page>

arguments.name: id
arguments.description: The unique id of your action.

arguments.name: func
arguments.description:
The function to be executed.

<callback>
<arg type="Player" name="ply">The player who pressed the button</arg>
<arg type="vararg" name="data">The 4th and all subsequent arguments passed from <page>numpad.OnDown</page> and/or <page>numpad.OnUp</page>.</arg>
<ret type="boolean" name="data" default="nil">Returning `false` in this function will remove the listener which triggered this function

(example: return `false` if one of your varargs is an entity which is no longer valid)</ret>
</callback>

functions.name: Remove
functions.description: Removes a function added by either <page>numpad.OnUp</page> or <page>numpad.OnDown</page>

arguments.name: ID
arguments.description: The impulse ID returned by <page>numpad.OnUp</page> or <page>numpad.OnDown</page>

functions.name: Toggle
functions.description: Either runs <page>numpad.Activate</page> or <page>numpad.Deactivate</page> depending on the key's current state

arguments.name: ply
arguments.description: The player whose numpad should be simulated

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key to press, corresponding to <page>Enums/KEY</page>

name: os
description: The os library is a standard Lua library originally intended to allow Lua access to various features of the Operating System it's running on, however many of the features and functions have been removed in Garry's Mod due to security issues. It's only used in Garry's Mod for date & time operations.

functions.name: clock
functions.description:
Returns the approximate cpu time the application ran.
See also <page>Global.SysTime</page>
<note>This function has different precision on Linux (1/100).</note>

functions.name: date
functions.description: Returns the date/time as a formatted string or in a table.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description:
The format string.

If this is equal to `*t` or `!*t` then this function will return a <page>Structures/DateData</page>, otherwise it will return a string.

If this starts with an `!`, the returned data will use the UTC timezone rather than the local timezone.

See http://www.mkssoftware.com/docs/man3/strftime.3.asp for available format flags.

<bug issue="329">**Not all flags are available on all operating systems** and the result of using an invalid flag is undefined. This currently crashes the game on Windows. Most or all flags are available on OS X and Linux but considerably fewer are available on Windows. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fe06s4ak.aspx for a list of available flags on Windows. Note that the **#** flags also crashes the game on Windows.</bug>

Known formats that work on all platforms:

| Format | Description | Example of the output |
|:------:|:-----------:|:---------------------:|
| `%a` | Abbreviated weekday name | `Wed` |
| `%A` | Full weekday name | `Wednesday` |
| `%b` | Abbreviated month name | `Sep` |
| `%B` | Full month name | `September` |
| `%c` | Locale-appropriate date and time | Varies by platform and language settings |
| `%d` | Day of the month [01-31] | `16` |
| `%H` | Hour, using a 24-hour clock [00-23] | `23` |
| `%I` | Hour, using a 12-hour clock [01-12] | `11` |
| `%j` | Day of the year [001-365] | `259` |
| `%m` | Month [01-12] | `09` |
| `%M` | Minute [00-59] | `48` |
| `%p` | Either `am` or `pm` | `pm` |
| `%S` | Second [00-60] | `10` |
| `%w` | Weekday [0-6 = Sunday-Saturday] | `3` |
| `%W` | Week of the year [00-53] | `37` |
| `%x` | Date (Same as `%m/%d/%y`) | `09/16/98` |
| `%X` | Time (Same as `%H:%M:%S`) | `23:48:10` |
| `%y` | Two-digit year [00-99] | `98` |
| `%Y` | Full year | `1998` |
| `%z` | Timezone | `-0300` |
| `%%` | A percent sign | `%` |

arguments.name: time
arguments.description: Time to use for the format.

returnValues.description:
Formatted date
<note>This will be a <page>Structures/DateData</page> if the first argument equals to `*t` or `!*t`</note>

functions.name: difftime
functions.description: Subtracts the second from the first value and rounds the result.

arguments.name: timeA
arguments.description: The first value.

arguments.name: timeB
arguments.description: The value to subtract.

functions.name: time
functions.description: Returns the system time in seconds past the unix epoch. If a table is supplied, the function attempts to build a system time with the specified table members.

arguments.name: dateData
arguments.description: Table to generate the time from. This table's data is interpreted as being in the local timezone. See <page>Structures/DateData</page>

name: package
description: The package library is a standard Lua library, it's mainly for use with the module system built into Lua.

functions.name: loaded
functions.description: A list of all loaded packages.

returnValues.description: The list of all loaded packages.

name: permissions
description: Used to ask player for various potentially dangerous permissions.

functions.name: AskToConnect
functions.description: Requests the player to connect to a specified server. The player will be prompted with a confirmation window.

arguments.name: address
arguments.description: The address to ask to connect to. If a port is not given, the default `:27015` port will be added.

functions.name: Connect
functions.description: Connects player to the server. This is what <page>permissions.AskToConnect</page> uses internally.

arguments.name: ip
arguments.description: IP address to connect.

functions.name: EnableVoiceChat
functions.description:
Activates player's microphone as if they pressed the speak button themself. The player will be prompted with a confirmation window which grants permission temporarily/permanently(depending on checkbox state) for the connected server (revokable).
This is used for TTT's traitor voice channel.

arguments.name: enable
arguments.description: Enable or disable voice activity. `true` will run `+voicerecord` command, anything else `-voicerecord`.

functions.name: GetAll
functions.description: Returns all permissions per server. Permanent permissions are stored in `settings/permissions.bin`.

functions.name: IsGranted
functions.description: Returns whether the player has granted the current server a specific permission.

arguments.name: permission
arguments.description:
The permission to poll. Currently only 2 permission are valid:
* `"connect"`
* `"voicerecord"`

returnValues.description: Whether the permission is granted or not.

functions.name: Revoke
functions.description: Revokes permission from the server.

arguments.name: permission
arguments.description: Permission to revoke from the server.

arguments.name: ip
arguments.description: IP of the server.

name: physenv
description: The physenv library allows you to control the physics environment created by the engine, and lets you modify constants such as gravity and maximum velocity.

functions.name: AddSurfaceData
functions.description:
Adds surface properties to the game's physics environment.

<bug issue="2604">The game has a limit of 128 surface properties - this includes properties loaded automatically from [surfaceproperties.txt](https://github.com/Facepunch/garrysmod/blob/master/garrysmod/scripts/surfaceproperties.txt). Due to this, there's only a small amount of open slots that can be registered with GMod's provided surfaceproperties.txt.</bug>

arguments.name: properties
arguments.description: The properties to add. Each one should include "base" or the game will crash due to some values being missing.

functions.name: GetAirDensity
functions.description:
Returns the air density used to calculate drag on physics objects.
<validate>The unit is in `kg/m³`.</validate>

functions.name: GetGravity
functions.description: Gets the gravitational acceleration used for physics objects in `source_unit/s^2`.

functions.name: GetLastSimulationTime
functions.description: Returns the last simulation duration of the in-game physics.

returnValues.description: The last simulation duration of the in-game physics in seconds

functions.name: GetPerformanceSettings
functions.description: Gets the current performance settings in table form.

functions.name: GetPhysicsPaused
functions.description: Returns the pause status of global physics simulation. See <page>physenv.SetPhysicsPaused</page> for the setter.

functions.name: SetAirDensity
functions.description: Sets the air density.

arguments.name: airDensity
arguments.description: The new air density.

functions.name: SetGravity
functions.description: Sets the gravitational acceleration used for physics objects. Does not affect players.

arguments.name: gravAccel
arguments.description: The new gravity in `source_unit/s^2`.

functions.name: SetPerformanceSettings
functions.description: Sets the performance settings.

arguments.name: performanceSettings
arguments.description: The new performance settings. See <page>Structures/PhysEnvPerformanceSettings</page>

functions.name: SetPhysicsPaused
functions.description: Pauses or unpauses the physics simulation globally. See <page>physenv.GetPhysicsPaused</page> for the getter.

arguments.name: pause
arguments.description: `true` to pause, `false` to unpause.

name: player
description: The player library is used to get the Lua objects that represent players in-game.

functions.name: CreateNextBot
functions.description:
Similar to the serverside command "bot", this function creates a new Player bot with the given name. This bot will not obey to the usual "bot_*" commands, and it's the same bot base used in TF2 and CS:S.

The best way to control the behaviour of a Player bot right now is to use the <page>GM:StartCommand</page> hook and modify its input serverside.

<note>Despite this Player being fake, it has to be removed from the server by using <page>Player:Kick</page> and **NOT** <page>Entity:Remove</page>.
Also keep in mind that these bots still use player slots, so you won't be able to spawn them in singleplayer!</note>

<note>Any Bot created using this method will be considered UnAuthed by Garry's Mod</note>

arguments.name: botName
arguments.description:
The name of the bot, using an already existing name will append brackets at the end of it with a number pertaining it.

Example: "Bot name test", "Bot name test(1)".

returnValues.description: The newly created Player bot. Returns NULL if there's no Player slots available to host it.

functions.name: GetAll
functions.description:
Gets all the current players in the server (not including connecting clients).

This function returns bots as well as human players. See <page>player.GetBots</page> and  <page>player.GetHumans</page>.

<note>This function returns a sequential table, meaning it should be looped with <page>Global.ipairs</page> instead of <page>Global.pairs</page> for efficiency reasons.</note>

functions.name: GetBots
functions.description: Returns a table of all bots on the server.

returnValues.description: A table only containing bots ( AI / non human players )

functions.name: GetByAccountID
functions.description:
Tried to get the player with the specified <page>Player:AccountID</page>.
<warning>Internally this function iterates over all players in the server, meaning it can be quite expensive in a performance-critical context.</warning>

arguments.name: accountID
arguments.description: The <page>Player:AccountID</page> to find the player by.

returnValues.description: Player if one is found, `false` otherwise.

functions.name: GetByID
functions.description:
Gets the player with the specified connection ID.

Connection ID can be retrieved via <page>gameevent.Listen</page> events.

For a function that returns a player based on their <page>Entity:EntIndex</page>, see <page>Global.Entity</page>.


For a function that returns a player based on their <page>Player:UserID</page>, see <page>Global.Player</page>.

arguments.name: connectionID
arguments.description: The connection ID to find the player by.

returnValues.description: Player if one is found, `nil` otherwise.

functions.name: GetBySteamID
functions.description:
Gets the player with the specified SteamID.
<warning>Internally this function iterates over all players in the server, meaning it can be quite expensive in a performance-critical context.</warning>

arguments.name: steamID
arguments.description: The <page>Player:SteamID</page> to find the player by.

returnValues.description: Player if one is found, `false` otherwise.

functions.name: GetBySteamID64
functions.description:
Gets the player with the specified SteamID64.
<warning>Internally this function iterates over all players in the server, meaning it can be quite expensive in a performance-critical context.</warning>

arguments.name: steamID64
arguments.description: The <page>Player:SteamID64</page> to find the player by.

returnValues.description: Player if one is found, `false` otherwise.

functions.name: GetByUniqueID
functions.description:
<deprecated>Use <page>player.GetBySteamID64</page>, <page>player.GetBySteamID</page> or <page>player.GetByAccountID</page> to get a player by a unique identifier instead.</deprecated>

Gets the player with the specified uniqueID (not recommended way to identify players).

<warning>It is highly recommended to use <page>player.GetByAccountID</page>, <page>player.GetBySteamID</page> or <page>player.GetBySteamID64</page> instead as this function can have collisions ( be same for different people ) while SteamID is guaranteed to unique to each player.</warning>
<warning>Internally this function iterates over all players in the server, meaning it can be quite expensive in a performance-critical context.</warning>

arguments.name: uniqueID
arguments.description: The <page>Player:UniqueID</page> to find the player by.

returnValues.description: Player if one is found, `false` otherwise.

functions.name: GetCount
functions.description:
Gives you the player count.

<note>Similar to **#**<page>player.GetAll</page>() but with better performance since the player table doesn't have to be generated. If <page>player.GetAll</page> is already being called for iteration, then using the **#** operator on the table will be faster than calling this function since it is JITted.</note>

functions.name: GetHumans
functions.description:
Returns a table containing all human players (non-bot/AI).

Unlike <page>player.GetAll</page>, this does not include bots.
<note>This function returns a sequential table, meaning it should be looped with <page>Global.ipairs</page> instead of <page>Global.pairs</page> for efficiency reasons.</note>

returnValues.description: A table containing all human (non-bot/AI) players.

functions.name: Iterator
functions.description:
Returns a [Stateless Iterator](https://www.lua.org/pil/7.3.html) for all players on the server.
Intended for use in [Generic For Loops](https://www.lua.org/pil/4.3.5.html).
See <page>ents.Iterator</page> for a similar function for all entities.

Internally, this function uses cached values that exist entirely within lua, as opposed to <page>player.GetAll</page>, which is a C++ function.
Because switching from lua to C++ (and vice versa) incurs a performance cost, this function will be somewhat more efficient than <page>player.GetAll</page>.
<note>The <page>GM:OnEntityCreated</page> and <page>GM:EntityRemoved</page> hooks are used internally to invalidate this function's cache. Using this function inside those hooks is not guaranteed to use an up-to-date cache because hooks are currently executed in an arbitrary order.</note>
<warning>An error being thrown inside the <page>GM:OnEntityCreated</page> or <page>GM:EntityRemoved</page> hooks is likely to break this function. Make it certain that no addons are causing any errors in those hooks.</warning>

returnValues.description:
Table of all existing <page text="Players">Player</page>.  This is a cached copy of <page>player.GetAll</page>
<warning>This table is intended to be read-only.

Modifying the return table will affect all subsequent calls to this function until the cache is refreshed, replacing all of your player.GetAll usages may come with unintended side effects because of this.

Example of bad code:
```
-- NEVER DO THIS!!!

local scan_ents = select(2, player.Iterator())

table.Add(scan_ents, ents.FindByClass("ttt_decoy"))
```
</warning>

The starting index for the table of players.
This is always `0` and is returned for the benefit of [Generic For Loops](https://www.lua.org/pil/4.3.5.html)

Retrieves correct hands for given player model. By default returns citizen hands.

<note>See <page>player_manager.AddValidHands</page> for defining/linking hands to a model - this must be defined somewhere otherwise the model will return citizen hands here.</note>

returnValues.description: The simplified name for that model

<internal></internal>

description: The properties library gives you access to the menu that shows up when right clicking entities while holding C.

arguments.description: A table that defines the property. Uses the <page>Structures/PropertyAdd</page>.

Returns true if given entity can be targeted by the player via the properties system.

This should be used serverside in your properties to prevent abuse by clientside scripting.

arguments.name: pos
